G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises from Defendant’s violation of the statutory and common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment appurtenant to Plaintiff’s tenancy at the Premises, in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the events giving rise to this complaint occurred within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court and the damages sought are within the monetary jurisdiction of the District Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the events giving rise to this complaint occurred within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court and the damages sought are within the monetary jurisdiction of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the cause of action arose in Somerville, Middlesex County, where the leased Premises are located and where Defendant transacts business as a landlord.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Independently of the Lease language, Massachusetts law implies into every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment and prohibits landlords from interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court repeatedly refers to an "implied" covenant/warranty of quiet enjoyment as the basis for the tenants’ constructive eviction defense, without grounding that covenant in any specific lease language. It treats the covenant as a background obligation of the landlord under Massachusetts law and applies it to prohibit the landlord’s interference (via operation and control of the lounge) with the tenants’ quiet enjoyment of their apartments. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts law implies such a covenant into every residential tenancy, independent of express lease terms.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were "very substantially deprived" of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises "for a substantial time" (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge)… Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Independently of the Lease language, Massachusetts law implies into every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment and prohibits landlords from interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explicitly discusses the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts, stating that “[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.” It further explains that the phrase “quiet enjoyment” has a settled meaning in landlord-tenant law, independent of lease language, and that liability can arise based on the landlord’s conduct that interferes with that right. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts law implies such a covenant into every residential tenancy and prohibits landlord interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s inaction and dismissive response, in the face of continuous and foreseeable interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy caused by another tenant under Defendant’s control, constitutes an unreasonable and substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord’s failure to take available measures to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity, when that activity seriously interferes with tenants’ use of the premises, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion explicitly ties liability to what the landlord failed to do in the face of serious, foreseeable interference occurring in common areas under the landlord’s control, which aligns with the proposition that such inaction and dismissiveness may be an unreasonable and substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s inaction and dismissive response, in the face of continuous and foreseeable interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy caused by another tenant under Defendant’s control, constitutes an unreasonable and substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case is not about tenant-on-tenant misconduct, but the Court articulates the governing standard under G.L. c. 186, § 14: a landlord’s liability requires at least negligent conduct where the natural and probable consequence is interference with the tenant’s rights, and includes situations where the landlord "stood idle" despite complaints and the problem was foreseeable and correctable. That framework supports the proposition that a landlord’s inaction and dismissive response, in the face of continuous and foreseeable interference by someone under the landlord’s control, can constitute an unreasonable and substantial interference with quiet enjoyment, though the facts here involve lead paint rather than another tenant.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the " 'natural and probable consequence' of a landlord's action was interruption of the tenant's rights." Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102, quoting Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942). In Cruz, we observed that the landlord had notice of the defects in the leased premises which it failed to repair, and that it was "wholly foreseeable" that the injury to the tenant would result from this failure to make the repairs. Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant's quiet enjoyment of the premises.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 982–83 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial and chronic disturbances—such as excessive noise, threats, or other conditions interfering with sleep and peace in the home—can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, focusing specifically on lack of heat as the substantial interference. It does not address excessive noise, threats, or other disturbances affecting sleep or peace in the home, so it cannot be cited as authority for that broader proposition about “substantial and chronic disturbances” generally. The case is good authority for heat-related deprivations as a breach, not for noise or threat-based disturbances.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited. It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–78 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: The interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment was not de minimis or occasional, but significant, repetitive, and continuing, depriving Plaintiff of basic sleep and rest and substantially reducing the value and habitability of the Premises to Plaintiff.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion certainly describes very serious, ongoing habitability problems (no heat, rodent and cockroach infestations, other serious defects over a two‑year period), but the cited portion of Cruz Mgmt. v. Wideman is focused on the proper *measure of damages* for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a Section 8 tenancy, not on the legal standard for or characterization of interference with quiet enjoyment. The court even notes that although the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, no damages were awarded on that claim to avoid duplication, and the opinion does not analyze whether the interference was substantial, repetitive, or affected sleep/rest or habitability in the way the proposition states. Thus, it provides factual background of serious conditions but does not establish the specific legal proposition claimed.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Wideman’s tenancy with Cruz Management commenced on or about May 18, 1988. She vacated her apartment, located at 228 Magnolia Street, in the Dorchester section of Boston, some time in October, 1990. During her tenancy, she and her two sons endured continuing infestations of rodents and cockroaches. Heat in the apartment ranged from nonexistent (at worst) to insufficient (at best). Cruz Management had notice of these defects, as well as others, which the judge found existed... Most of the violations remained uncorrected through October, 1990, when Wideman finally vacated.
